questions.question: The people who run governments must be kept in ____.

choices.answer: isolation
check
jail
high reverence

questions.question: Which statement describes an essential part of the rule of law?

choices.answer: Government officials are not above the law.
The public does not approve every law.
Citizens decide the authority of the law.
Citizens decide the authority of the law.

questions.question: One of the basic ideals of American government is that ___________ ?

choices.answer: Government should be based on the consent of the governed.
The Constitution should be easily amended.
The executive branch should be the most powerful branch.
Majority rule can be overruled by presidential veto.

questions.question: All of the following freedoms are protected in the United States EXCEPT

choices.answer: the freedom to learn.
the freedom to choose a job or a career.
the freedom to disregard the rights of others.
the freedom to own a house.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is INCORRECT?

choices.answer: Gov't makes possible big groups ppl to live peacefully.
Some form of government is found in every society.
The USA has a form of gov't called a direct democracy.
A govt’s important laws are stated in its constitution.

questions.question: How are the Enlightenment ideas that influenced Founding Fathers shown in modern institutions?

choices.answer: The European Union encourages economic stability.
Lands have been re-established to preserve pop. sovereignty
Oligarchies have increased to safeguard natural rights.
The United Nations promotes universal human rights.

questions.question: How does the quote below reflect the influence of the Enlightenment on the founding Fathers?

choices.answer: They supported individual liberties.
They had reservations about self-government.
They were concerned with property rights.
They created a limited monarchy.

questions.question: Which statement describes an essential part of the rule of law?

choices.answer: The public does not approve every law.
Citizens decide the authority of the law.
The courts decide the constitutionality of every law.
Government officials are not above the law.

questions.question: Which principle of the U.S. Constitution applies to all citizens?

choices.answer: checks and balances
rule of law
judicial review
separation of powers

questions.question: All cases involving claims of U.S. citizenship __________ .

choices.answer: must undergo a waiting period of 7 to 10 years.
are handled by the state governments.
are handled by the Immigration and Naturalization Service.
originate from refugees of foreign countries.

questions.question: All of the following are basic American freedoms EXCEPT the freedom to ___________ .

choices.answer: choose a job or career.
learn.
travel or live anywhere in the nation.
follow and obey only the laws with which one agrees.

questions.question: Which of the following is a quality of a good citizen?

choices.answer: never questions the government
disrespects the rights of others
respects and obeys the laws
ignores important issues

questions.question: The reward for doing volunteer work is

choices.answer: knowing that you have performed a valuable service.
financial.
being able to run for public office.
is credit at local stores and businesses.

questions.question: During an examination for naturalization, an applicant must

choices.answer: show that he or she believes in the Bible.
prove he can read, write, and speak English acceptably.
prove that he knows nothing about U.S. history and gov't.
submit to a lie-detector test.

questions.question: What do a republic and a direct democracy have in common?

choices.answer: a small group of leaders
a single leader
rule by a single political.party
rule by the people

questions.question: Our system of government only works if ___________ .

choices.answer: citizens agree with their elected representatives
citizens think for themselves.
citizens do not think critically.
citizens do not question others' opinions.

questions.question: When did the Nineteenth Amendment give women the right to vote?

choices.answer: 1826

questions.question: Our republic works successfully because most Americans believe ___________ .

choices.answer: in the idea of an absolute monarchy.
in the idea of majority rule.
in the Mayflower Compact.
in the same religion.

questions.question: This is from a historical paper. According to the quote, where should gov'ts get their power?

choices.answer: from the executive branch
from elected leaders
from the public
from the legislative branch

questions.question: What's the difference between the duties of citizenship & responsibilities of citizenship?

choices.answer: Responsibilities are required by law; duties are not.
Duties are required by law; responsibilities are not.
Duties're listed in Bill of Rights; responsibilities aren't.
The terms refer to the same thing.

questions.question: Which is a requirement for a person to become a naturalized U.S. citizen?

choices.answer: Marrying U.S. citizen & having a child with that person.
Reaching age eighteen while living in the U.S. capital.
Gaining employment in the U.S. for at least five years.
Being a legal resident of the U.S. for at least five years.

questions.question: Below is a state plate. Based on the image, what conclusion can be drawn about New Hampshire?

choices.answer: D. its residents support income taxes.
its residents value the right to bear arms.
its residents support tyrannical rule.
its residents value natural rights.

questions.question: Which public policy reflects the views of the citizen who wore the button pictured below.

choices.answer: youth literacy
youth employment
youth education
youth suffrage

questions.question: Which public policy perspective reflects the views of the author, Martin Luther King, Jr?

choices.answer: racial equality
racial segregation
racial prejudice
racial tolerance

questions.question: How does monarchy differ from other forms of government?

choices.answer: Leaders are named in the constitution.
Leaders are chosen by the upper class.
Leaders are born into ruling families.
Leaders are given power by kings.

questions.question: Below is a newspaper headline.

choices.answer: A
B
C
D

questions.question: Which enlightenment idea is represented by the image below?

choices.answer: social contract
separation of powers
checks and balances
natural law

questions.question: Which right is an example of an Enlightenment idea?

choices.answer: Fifth Amendment self-incrimination protection
First Amendment freedom of speech guarantees
First Amendment freedom of religion guarantees
Fourth Amendment search and seizure protection

questions.question: Which purpose of government can be traced to these statements?

choices.answer: Censure domestic tranquility
provide for the common defense
promote the general welfare
establish justice

questions.question: Which idea is from the Magna Carta?

choices.answer: he people should be completely free from the government.
The people should support a strong central government.
The government should give people a fair and speedy trial.
The government should have unlimited power to tax.

questions.question: Which of the following did the reps to the Con'l Conv. adopt from the English Bill of Rights?

choices.answer: the right of each state to issue its own money
the right of Americans to be judged only by English law
the right, after found guilty, to receive fair punishment
the right to establish a one-house legislature

questions.question: Which action did the colonists use this cartoon to support?

choices.answer: Dissolving colonial legislatures.
Declaring independence from the British monarchy.
Declaring loyalty to the British monarchy.
Dissolving colonial charters.

questions.question: The Declaration of Independence

choices.answer: was written by Benjamin Franklin.
says the purpose of government is to protect human rights.
did not explain the reasons the  colonies separated from GB
was supposed to provide a government for the new USA

questions.question: Why did Parliament repeal the Stamp Act, which taxed goods such as newspapers and cards?

choices.answer: The colonists established a blockade against British goods.
The colonists were able to produce their own goods.
The colonists started destroying British goods.
The colonists began boycotting British goods.

questions.question: What was the significance of the stamp on the newspaper?

choices.answer: showed Parliament ignored colonists’ media communications.
showed Parliament controlled the colonists’ press outlets.
represented colonists’ opposition to English tax policies.
represented colonists’ fulfillment of English tax policies.

questions.question: Which document addressed colonial concerns about English policies?

choices.answer: Declaration of Independence
Mayflower Compact
U.S. Constitution
Bill of Rights

questions.question: Who was the principal author of the Declaration of Independence?

choices.answer: Thomas Jefferson
George Washington
John Adams
James Madison

questions.question: One of the basic ideals of American government is that

choices.answer: government should be based on the consent of the governed.
majority rule can be overruled by presidential veto.
the Constitution should be easily amended.
the executive branch should be the most powerful branch.

questions.question: What is the main idea of the passage?

choices.answer: Only citizens can enjoy rights guaranteed by government.
People have rights that cannot be denied by any government.
Government must equally distribute power among people.
Government is necessary to promote equality.

questions.question: Which document contains this passage?

choices.answer: Articles of Confederation
U.S. Constitution
English Bill of Rights
Declaration of Independence

questions.question: Which statement completes the diagram?

choices.answer: It is the role of government to determine natural rights.
It is the role of government to protect natural rights.
People establish natural rights.
People possess natural rights.

questions.question: Based on the passage, where should governments get their power?

choices.answer: from the legislative branch
from elected leaders
from the public
from the executive branch
